message_1: Suppose that the weights of apples in a certain orchard follow a normal distribution with a mean of 150 grams and a standard deviation of 10 grams. What proportion of apples in the orchard weighs less than 135 grams?
message_2:
To find the proportion of apples that weigh less than 135 grams, we can use the z-score formula to standardize the value and then use the standard normal distribution table (also known as the z-table) to find the proportion.

The z-score formula is:

z = (X - μ) / σ

where X is the value we want to standardize (135 grams in this case), μ is the mean (150 grams), and σ is the standard deviation (10 grams).

Plugging in the values, we get:

z = (135 - 150) / 10
z = -15 / 10
z = -1.5

Now, we look up the z-score of -1.5 in the standard normal distribution table. The table gives us the proportion of values to the left of the z-score (i.e., the proportion of apples weighing less than 135 grams).

Looking up -1.5 in the z-table, we find a proportion of approximately 0.0668.

So, about 6.68% of apples in the orchard weigh less than 135 grams.
